entities.description: "Professor McGonagall is anxious to discuss the disappearance of Dumbledore and the rumors surrounding the Potter family."
Albus Dumbledore is the highly respected headmaster of Hogwarts, considered one of the greatest wizards, who allowed Hagrid to stay on as gamekeeper after his expulsion.
Voldemort, also known as You-Know-Who, is a powerful dark wizard who killed Harry's parents and tried to kill Harry but failed, marking a significant event in the wizarding world.
"Godric's Hollow is the location where Voldemort attacked the Potter family."
"Lily Potter is a victim of Voldemort's attack, along with her husband James."
"James Potter is a victim of Voldemort's attack, along with his wife Lily."
"Harry Potter is the son of Lily and James Potter, who survived Voldemort's attack."
"Hagrid is entrusted by Dumbledore to bring Harry Potter to his aunt and uncle's house."
"Harry Potter Day is a potential future event where Harry Potter's survival and fame are celebrated."
"The Potters refer to Lily and James Potter, who were killed by Voldemort."
"Number Four is the location where Harry Potter's aunt and uncle live, as pointed out by Professor McGonagall."
"Harry's Aunt and Uncle are his only living relatives, who Dumbledore plans to send Harry to live with."
"Harry's Cousin is the son of Harry's aunt and uncle, who is described as ill-behaved."
"The Letter is written by Dumbledore to explain everything to Harry when he is older, to be given to Harry's aunt and uncle."
"The Motorcycle is the mode of transportation used by Hagrid, which lands in front of Dumbledore and McGonagall."
"The Huge Motorcycle is another description of Hagrid's mode of transportation, emphasizing its size."

relationships.description: "Professor McGonagall seeks information and reassurance from Dumbledore about the Potter family's fate."
"Dumbledore is aware of Voldemort's actions and their consequences on the Potter family and himself."
"Voldemort is responsible for the death of Lily Potter."
"Voldemort is responsible for the death of James Potter."
"Voldemort failed to kill Harry Potter, which led to the breaking of his power."
"Dumbledore is responsible for Harry Potter's safety and future, planning to bring him to his aunt and uncle."
"Dumbledore trusts Hagrid with the task of bringing Harry Potter to his relatives."
"Harry Potter is the central figure whose survival might lead to the establishment of Harry Potter Day."
"The Potters are Harry Potter's deceased parents."
"Number Four is the residence of Harry's Aunt and Uncle."
"Harry's Aunt and Uncle are the parents of Harry's Cousin."
"Dumbledore is the author of The Letter to be given to Harry's aunt and uncle."
"Hagrid is the rider of The Motorcycle."
"Hagrid is associated with The Huge Motorcycle, his mode of transportation."

entities.description: "Vernon is Harry's uncle who tries to prevent Harry from receiving letters by various means, including tearing them up and boarding up the mail slot."
The main character who receives a mysterious letter and is a student at Stonewall High, also addressed as Mr. H. Potter in the letter.
"Petunia is Harry's aunt and Vernon's wife, who is involved in the attempts to stop the letters from reaching Harry."
"Dudley is the son of Vernon and Petunia, and Harry's cousin, who is also involved in the family's escape to avoid the letters."
"Railview Hotel Cokeworth is a gloomy-looking hotel on the outskirts of a big city where the family stays to avoid the letters."

The Letters to Harry Potter is the event where numerous letters addressed in green ink are sent to Harry, causing Vernon Dursley to take drastic measures to prevent their delivery, such as tearing them up, boarding up the mail slot, and fleeing from home.
"Aunt Petunia is Harry's aunt, married to Vernon, and is involved in the attempts to stop the letters from reaching Harry."
"The milkman is the person confused by the unusual delivery of letters hidden inside eggs, which are addressed to Harry."
"The Post Office is the organization from which the mysterious letters addressed in green ink are sent to Harry."
"The Dairy is the organization that delivers milk and is contacted by Vernon in an attempt to complain about the delivery of letters hidden in eggs."
"The forest is the location where Vernon drives the family in an attempt to escape the letters, showing his desperation."
"Breakfast at the Hotel is the event where the hotel owner approaches the family about the letters addressed to Mr. H. Potter."
"Escape from Home is the event where Vernon decides to take the family away from their home to avoid the letters being delivered to Harry."

relationships.description: "Vernon is trying to prevent Harry from receiving the mysterious letters."
"Vernon is actively involved in preventing the delivery of the letters to Harry."
"Harry is the intended recipient of the numerous letters sent in green ink."
"Petunia assists Vernon in trying to prevent the letters from reaching Harry."
"Dudley is indirectly affected by the letters as he is part of the family's efforts to avoid them."
"Vernon takes his family to stay at the Railview Hotel Cokeworth in an attempt to escape the letters."
"Aunt Petunia is part of the family trying to prevent Harry from receiving the letters."
"The milkman is involved in the unusual delivery of letters to Harry, hiding them inside eggs."
"The Post Office is the source of the mysterious letters sent to Harry."
"Vernon contacts the Dairy in an attempt to complain about the delivery of letters hidden in eggs."
"Vernon drives the family to the forest as part of their escape to avoid the letters."
"Vernon is present during the breakfast at the hotel when the owner approaches them about the letters for Harry."
"Vernon initiates the escape from home to avoid the letters being delivered to Harry."

entities.description: "Hagrid is a giant who is entrusted with the task of delivering a baby boy, Harry, to the Dursleys' house."
Albus Dumbledore is the highly respected headmaster of Hogwarts, considered one of the greatest wizards, who allowed Hagrid to stay on as gamekeeper after his expulsion.
"Sirius Black is the person from whom Hagrid borrowed the motorcycle, indicating his connection to the events surrounding Harry's delivery."
"Professor McGonagall is involved in the delivery of baby Harry and shares in the emotional response to his situation."
The main character who receives a mysterious letter and is a student at Stonewall High, also addressed as Mr. H. Potter in the letter.
"The Dursleys are the family to whom baby Harry is delivered, and they are Muggles, indicating their lack of magical abilities."
"Bristol is a location mentioned where Hagrid and Harry were lying over, indicating its relevance to their journey."
"The London Underground is mentioned as a metaphor for Dumbledore's scar, indicating its significance in the narrative."
"Privet Drive is the location where Harry is left at the Dursleys' house, and it is described as a quiet and tidy street."
"Muggles are non-magical people who Hagrid mentions to Dumbledore, indicating their potential interference in magical affairs."
"Lily is mentioned as deceased and is related to Harry, indicating her importance to his backstory."
"James is mentioned as deceased and is related to Harry, indicating his importance to Harry's backstory."
"Mrs. Dursley is a member of the Dursley family who will discover Harry on her doorstep."
"Dudley is Harry's cousin who will interact with him in the coming weeks, as indicated by the text."
"Secret People are those meeting in secret all over the country, toasting Harry as 'the boy who lived'."
"The event is a secret toast made by people all over the country in honor of Harry's survival, indicating his fame and the significance of his survival."

relationships.description: "Hagrid reports to Dumbledore and follows his instructions in delivering baby Harry to the Dursleys."
"Hagrid borrowed the motorcycle from Sirius Black, indicating a connection or friendship between them."
"Dumbledore and Professor McGonagall work together in the delivery of baby Harry and share in the emotional response to the situation."
"Harry is delivered to the Dursleys' house, indicating their future role as his guardians."
"Hagrid is responsible for delivering baby Harry to the Dursleys' house and shows emotional attachment to him."
"Dumbledore is involved in the decision to leave Harry at the Dursleys' house and has a direct role in his care."
"Muggles are the non-magical community that will inadvertently be involved in Harry's life as he is left with the Dursleys, a Muggle family."
"Lily is Harry's deceased mother, which is a significant relationship in understanding his backstory and family."
"James is Harry's deceased father, which is a significant relationship in understanding his backstory and family."
"Mrs. Dursley will be the one to find Harry on her doorstep, marking the beginning of their relationship."
"Dudley is Harry's cousin who will interact with him, indicating a family relationship and potential for conflict."
"The Secret People are toasting Harry, indicating their recognition of his significance and survival."

entities.description: "Dudley is a character who interacts with the snake at the zoo, showing impatience and a desire for the snake to move."
"Uncle Vernon is Dudley's father, who tries to get the snake to move by tapping on the glass."
The main character who receives a mysterious letter and is a student at Stonewall High, also addressed as Mr. H. Potter in the letter.
"Aunt Petunia is a character who is involved in the aftermath of the snake's escape, receiving an apology from the zoo director."
"Piers is a character who is present during the snake's escape and is frightened by the event."
"The Boa Constrictor is a snake from Brazil, currently housed in a zoo, which has a significant interaction with Harry."
"The zoo is the location where the snake is housed and where the main events of the story take place."
"The Snake's Escape is the event where the Boa Constrictor breaks out of its enclosure, causing panic among the visitors."
"The Dursleys are the family with whom Harry has lived for almost ten years, providing a negative and oppressive environment for him."
"Brazil is the country of origin for the Boa Constrictor, though the snake was bred in the zoo and has never been there."
"The Car Crash is the event in which Harry's parents died, leaving him to be raised by the Dursleys."
"Harry's parents are deceased, having died in a car crash. Their absence and the lack of information about them are significant to Harry's character."
"The Cupboard is where Harry is punished to stay by Uncle Vernon,象征着Harry's confinement and mistreatment by the Dursleys."
"The Reptile House is the section of the zoo where the Boa Constrictor is housed and where the snake's escape takes place."
"The Keeper of the Reptile House is an individual who is in shock over the disappearance of the glass front of the snake's tank."
"The Zoo Director is responsible for apologizing to Aunt Petunia and making her a cup of tea after the snake's escape."

relationships.description: "Dudley is fascinated by the Boa Constrictor and tries to get it to move, but is later frightened by its escape."
"Uncle Vernon attempts to get the Boa Constrictor to move by tapping on the glass, but is later involved in the aftermath of its escape."
"Harry has a unique interaction with the Boa Constrictor, including a wink and a conversation, and is possibly involved in its escape."
"Aunt Petunia is part of the family that experiences the aftermath of the Snake's Escape and receives an apology from the zoo director."
"Piers is present during the Snake's Escape and is frightened by the event, exaggerating the蛇's actions later."
"The Zoo is the location where the Snake's Escape takes place, causing panic and confusion among the visitors and staff."
"Harry has lived with the Dursleys for almost ten years, enduring a miserable and oppressive environment."
"Harry's life was significantly impacted by the Car Crash in which his parents died, leading to his upbringing by the Dursleys."
"Harry is often punished to stay in the Cupboard by Uncle Vernon, symbolizing his mistreatment by the Dursleys."
"The Keeper of the Reptile House is left in shock and confusion following the Snake's Escape."
"The Zoo Director is involved in managing the aftermath of the Snake's Escape, apologizing to Aunt Petunia and attempting to calm the situation."

entities.description: "Vernon is a character who is actively trying to avoid going home and leads the family to various locations before ending up on a rock in the sea."
"Aunt Petunia is a character who timidly suggests going home and is involved in the family's journey to the rock."
"Dudley is a character who is concerned about missing television and is part of the family's journey to the rock."
The main character who receives a mysterious letter and is a student at Stonewall High, also addressed as Mr. H. Potter in the letter.
"The forest is one of the locations Vernon drives the family to before they end up on the rock."
"The plowed field is another location Vernon drives the family to before they end up on the rock."
"The suspension bridge is a location Vernon drives the family to before they end up on the rock."
"The multilevel parking garage is a location Vernon drives the family to before they end up on the rock."
"The coast is where Vernon parks the car and disappears, later returning with a package and a plan to go to the rock."
"The rock is a large rock out at sea where Vernon leads the family to a shack, intending to avoid mail delivery."
"The shack is a miserable little house on top of the rock where the family takes shelter during a storm."
"The storm is a weather event that occurs while the family is on the rock, making conditions miserable inside the shack."
"Harry's eleventh birthday is an event that is approaching, which Harry contemplates while waiting for the storm to pass."
"Privet Drive is the location of the Dursleys' home, where Harry hopes to find letters upon their return."
"The Great Humberto is a television event that Dudley is eager to watch, indicating its importance to him."
"The toothless old man is a character who lends his boat to Vernon, facilitating the family's journey to the rock."
"The boat is the means of transportation Vernon uses to take the family to the rock, making them feel uncomfortable due to the cold and icy conditions."

The Letters to Harry Potter is the event where numerous letters addressed in green ink are sent to Harry, causing Vernon Dursley to take drastic measures to prevent their delivery, such as tearing them up, boarding up the mail slot, and fleeing from home.
"The riłe is a weapon Vernon carries, which was previously hidden in the long, thin package he brought with him."

relationships.description: "Vernon and Aunt Petunia are related as family members, with Vernon leading the family on a journey and Aunt Petunia suggesting they go home."
"Vernon and Dudley are related as family members, with Vernon leading the family on a journey and Dudley expressing concern about missing television."
"Vernon and Harry are related as family members, with Vernon leading the family on a journey and Harry being left to sleep on the floor in the shack."
"Vernon drives the family to the forest as part of their journey to avoid going home."
"Vernon drives the family to the plowed field as part of their journey to avoid going home."
"Vernon drives the family to the suspension bridge as part of their journey to avoid going home."
"Vernon drives the family to the multilevel parking garage as part of their journey to avoid going home."
"Privet Drive is the location where Harry hopes to find letters upon their return from the rock."
"Dudley is eager to watch The Great Humberto on television, indicating its importance to him."
"The toothless old man lends his boat to Vernon, which is used to take the family to the rock."
"Vernon carries a riłe, which was hidden in the long, thin package he brought with him."
"The storm is an event that prevents the delivery of the letters, which Vernon hopes will keep them from reaching the family on the rock."

entities.description: "Harry Potter is the central character, known as 'the boy who lived', living with his relatives, the Dursleys, and is treated poorly by them."
"Dudley Dursley is Harry's cousin, portrayed as a large, spoiled boy who is the son of the Dursleys and receives a lot of attention and gifts."
"Aunt Petunia is Harry's aunt by marriage, who is harsh and demanding towards him, often making him do chores and treating him poorly."
"Uncle Vernon is Harry's uncle by marriage, who is stern and unkind, often barking orders at Harry and not showing him any affection."
"Privet Drive is the location where the Dursleys live, and where Harry resides, characterized by its tidy front gardens and the Dursleys' house number four."
"Duddy's birthday is an event where Dudley expects a lot of presents and attention, and Harry is made to help with the preparations and cooking."
"Mr. Dursley is Harry's uncle by marriage, who saw a fateful news report about the owls and is part of the family that mistreats Harry."
"Auntie Marge is a relative of the Dursleys, mentioned as having a present for Dudley, indicating a familial connection."
"The Owls refer to a significant event or phenomenon that Mr. Dursley saw in a news report, possibly related to the magical world."
"The Cupboard Under the Stairs is where Harry sleeps, indicating his poor treatment by the Dursleys and the small, dark space he is confined to."
"The Car Crash is a tragic event in which Harry's parents died, leaving him with a lightning-bolt shaped scar on his forehead."
"Harry's Parents are deceased and their death is connected to the car crash, leaving Harry with his aunt and uncle."
"The Lightning Bolt Scar is a distinctive feature on Harry's forehead, shaped like a bolt of lightning, and is a result of the car crash that killed his parents."

relationships.description: "Harry Potter and Dudley Dursley are cousins, with Dudley being the son of Harry's aunt and uncle, and Harry being treated poorly in comparison to Dudley."
"Harry Potter is under the care of Aunt Petunia, who is harsh and demanding towards him, making him do chores and not showing him affection."
"Harry Potter is under the care of Uncle Vernon, who is stern and unkind, often barking orders at Harry and not showing him any affection."
"Dudley Dursley is the son of Aunt Petunia and is shown a lot of affection and attention, receiving many gifts for his birthday."
"Dudley Dursley is the son of Uncle Vernon and looks a lot like him, receiving a lot of attention and gifts for his birthday."
"Aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon are married and are the parents of Dudley Dursley, treating Harry poorly in comparison to their son."
"Harry Potter lives on Privet Drive with his aunt and uncle, the Dursleys, in a house that has hardly changed over the years."
"Dudley Dursley is the center of attention during his birthday event, receiving many gifts and expecting everything to be perfect."
"Harry Potter is the nephew of Mr. Dursley, who is part of the family that mistreats him."
"Mr. Dursley saw a fateful news report about the owls, which is an event that might be related to the magical world and has an impact on his family."
"Harry Potter sleeps in the cupboard under the stairs, indicating his poor treatment by the Dursleys and the small, dark space he is confined to."
"Harry Potter has a lightning-bolt shaped scar on his forehead as a result of the car crash that killed his parents."
"Harry's parents died in the car crash, leaving Harry with a lightning-bolt shaped scar and under the care of his aunt and uncle."
"Harry Potter is the son of his deceased parents, who left him with a lightning-bolt shaped scar and under the care of his aunt and uncle."
"The lightning-bolt shaped scar on Harry's forehead is a direct result of the car crash that killed his parents."

entities.description: The main character who receives a mysterious letter and is a student at Stonewall High, also addressed as Mr. H. Potter in the letter.
"Uncle Vernon is part of the Dursley family, appears to be the head of the household, and is initially hostile towards the giant."
"Dudley is a member of the Dursley family, described as fearful and hiding behind his mother during the encounter with the giant."
"Rubeus Hagrid is a giant who works as the Keeper of Keys and Grounds at Hogwarts, and he brings Harry a birthday cake."
"Hogwarts is the school where Rubeus Hagrid works and is implied to be a significant place for Harry."
"Dursley refers to the family that includes Uncle Vernon, Dudley, and Harry's aunt, who are all present during the encounter with Hagrid."
"The Hut is the location where the Dursley family resides and where the interaction with Hagrid takes place."
"Aunt is part of the Dursley family, and is present during the encounter with Hagrid, showing fear and protecting Dudley."
"The cannon is an object mentioned in the text, which Harry inquires about, indicating its relevance to the situation."
"The rifle is the weapon Uncle Vernon holds, which Hagrid takes from him and bends into a knot, showcasing Hagrid's strength."
"The door is a significant object in the text, as it is forcefully opened by Hagrid, symbolizing the beginning of the encounter."
"The storm is an environmental event happening outside the hut, adding to the atmosphere and the dramatic entrance of Hagrid."
"The chocolate cake is a gift from Hagrid to Harry for his birthday, inscribed with 'Happy Birthday Harry' and is a central object in the scene."
"Sausages are food items that Hagrid cooks and offers to Harry, contributing to the development of the scene and character interaction."
"The fireplace is the location where Hagrid magically creates a fire, providing warmth and light to the damp hut."
"Tea is a beverage that Hagrid requests and eventually makes, indicating his comfort in the Dursley's home despite the tension."
"The amber liquid is an alcoholic drink that Hagrid consumes, adding to the characterization of his rough and ready nature."

relationships.description: "Hagrid brings Harry a birthday cake and identifies himself as someone who works at the school Harry will attend, indicating a connection."
"Uncle Vernon is hostile towards Hagrid, demanding that he leave, and Hagrid responds dismissively to Vernon."
"Dudley is frightened by Hagrid's presence and hides behind his mother, while Hagrid teases Dudley about his size."
"Hagrid is an employee at Hogwarts, holding the position of Keeper of Keys and Grounds."
"Harry is implied to be a student at Hogwarts, as Hagrid mentions that he works there and brings Harry a birthday cake."
"Harry inquires about the cannon, showing his confusion and the cannon's relevance to the situation."
"Uncle Vernon is holding the rifle when Hagrid enters, and later Hagrid takes it from him, demonstrating Hagrid's dominance."
"The chocolate cake is a gift from Hagrid to Harry, marking a significant event in their interaction and Harry's birthday."

entities.description: "Grunnings is a firm that manufactures drills, where Mr. Dursley works as the director."
"Mr. Dursley is the director of Grunnings, a firm that makes drills, and is married to Mrs. Dursley."
"Mrs. Dursley is married to Mr. Dursley and is known for spying on the neighbors."
"Dudley is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dursley, and they believe there is no finer boy anywhere."
"The Potters are relatives of the Dursleys, with a son who is kept a secret from Dudley."
"Privet Drive is the location where the Dursley family lives, and where strange occurrences begin to happen."
"J.K. Rowling is the author of the story, with the book dedicated to specific individuals."
"Jim Kay is the illustrator of the book, contributing art and animation to enhance the story."
"Jessica is one of the individuals to whom J.K. Rowling dedicated the book, indicating her importance to the author."
"Anne is another person to whom J.K. Rowling dedicated the book, showing she was significant to the author."
"Di is the person who first heard the story according to J.K. Rowling's dedication, marking her as an early audience member."
"Louise is mentioned in Jim Kay's dedication, associated with the phrase 'unfathomable love'."
"Mr. Potter is the husband of Mrs. Potter and is considered unDursleyish by the Dursleys."
"Harry Potter is the son of the Potters and is kept a secret from the Dursleys."
"The Dursleys' Secret refers to the existence of the Potter family and their son, which the Dursleys fear will be discovered."

relationships.description: "Mr. Dursley is the director of Grunnings, indicating his leadership role in the organization."
"Mrs. Dursley is married to Mr. Dursley, establishing a familial relationship."
"Dudley is the son of Mr. Dursley, indicating a parent-child relationship."
"Dudley is the son of Mrs. Dursley, indicating a parent-child relationship."
"Mrs. Dursley is related to the Potter Family as she is the sister of Mrs. Potter, showing a familial connection."
"Mr. Dursley lives on Privet Drive with his family, indicating a residential relationship."
"Jessica is one of the individuals to whom J.K. Rowling dedicated the book, indicating a close relationship."
"Anne is another person to whom J.K. Rowling dedicated the book, indicating a close relationship."
"Di is the person who first heard the story according to J.K. Rowling's dedication, indicating a close relationship."
"Louise is mentioned in Jim Kay's dedication, associated with unfathomable love, indicating a close relationship."
"Harry Potter is the son of Mr. Potter, indicating a parent-child relationship."

entities.description: The main character who receives a mysterious letter and is a student at Stonewall High, also addressed as Mr. H. Potter in the letter.
"Uncle Vernon is a member of the Dursley family, trying to prevent Harry from receiving letters and is authoritarian in his actions."
"Aunt Petunia is a member of the Dursley family, involved in the decision to move Harry from the cupboard to Dudley's second bedroom."
"Dudley is a member of the Dursley family, who initially occupies the second bedroom that Harry is moved into and is upset about losing his room."
"Marge is Uncle Vernon's sister who usually occupies the visitors' bedroom in the Dursleys' house."
"4 Privet Drive is the address of the Dursleys' house where Harry is living and from which he receives letters."
"The Cupboard is the initial living space of Harry in the Dursleys' house, which he is moved out of."
"Dudley's Second Bedroom is the room Harry is moved into, which originally stored Dudley's toys and broken items."
"The Postman is responsible for delivering mail to the Dursleys' house, including letters addressed to Harry."
"The Smallest Bedroom is the room Harry is moved to, as indicated on the letters addressed to him."
"The Corner of Privet Drive is where Harry plans to wait for the postman to intercept his letters."
"The Mail is the delivery of letters to the Dursleys' house, which is a significant event as it contains letters for Harry."
"The Letter is a specific piece of mail addressed to Harry, which causes tension within the Dursley family."
"The Smelting Stick is an object Dudley uses to cause a commotion and fight over the letters."
"The Green Ink is used to write the letters addressed to Harry, making them distinct and noticeable."
"The Dog is a neighbor's pet that Dudley once drove a tank over, as indicated by the broken items in his room."
"The Parrot is a pet that Dudley once had, which is mentioned in the context of items in his room."
"The Air Rifle is an item Dudley had, which he acquired by trading a parrot at school."
"The Tortoise is a pet Dudley threw through the greenhouse roof in a fit of anger over Harry's room."
"The Video Camera is one of Dudley's broken toys mentioned in the description of his room."
"The Tank is a toy Dudley once drove over the neighbor's dog, as indicated by the broken items in his room."
"The Television Set is one of Dudley's broken items, which he destroyed when his favorite program was canceled."

relationships.description: "Harry is under the care of Uncle Vernon, who tries to control his access to mail and living situation."
"Harry lives with Aunt Petunia, who is involved in decisions affecting his living conditions."
"Harry is moved into the bedroom that Dudley previously used for his toys, causing tension between them."
"Dudley is Uncle Vernon's son, and they both are involved in trying to prevent Harry from receiving his letters."
"Uncle Vernon is the head of the household at 4 Privet Drive, where he tries to control the incoming mail for Harry."
"Harry originally lived in The Cupboard before being moved to Dudley's Second Bedroom."
"Harry is moved into Dudley's Second Bedroom, which changes his living situation within the Dursleys' house."
"Harry is expecting letters from The Postman, which are being intercepted by the Dursleys."
"Harry is moved to The Smallest Bedroom, as indicated on the letters he receives."
"Harry plans to wait at The Corner of Privet Drive to intercept his letters from the postman."
"Harry is expecting The Mail to contain important letters for him, which are being withheld by the Dursleys."
"Harry is the intended recipient of The Letter, which causes conflict within the Dursley family."
"Dudley uses The Smelting Stick to cause a disturbance and fight over the letters with Harry and Uncle Vernon."
"The Letter is written in The Green Ink, making it distinct and noticeable to Harry."

entities.description: Albus Dumbledore is the highly respected headmaster of Hogwarts, considered one of the greatest wizards, who allowed Hagrid to stay on as gamekeeper after his expulsion.

"Professor McGonagall is initially disguised as a cat and later appears as a severe-looking woman, discussing the celebrations and the potential exposure of the wizarding world to Muggles with Dumbledore."
"Mrs. Dursley is mentioned as someone with beady eyes who would not be able to see what is happening on the pavement due to the darkness created by Dumbledore."
"Muggles refers to the non-magical people who have noticed unusual activities, such as flocks of owls and shooting stars, and are potentially becoming aware of the wizarding world."
"Dedalus Diggle is mentioned as someone who might be responsible for the shooting stars in Kent, indicating his lack of sense according to Professor McGonagall."
Voldemort, also known as You-Know-Who, is a powerful dark wizard who killed Harry's parents and tried to kill Harry but failed, marking a significant event in the wizarding world.
"Kent is a location where shooting stars were observed, possibly caused by Dedalus Diggle, and is part of the discussion about the exposure of the wizarding world."
"The Put-Outer is a device used by Dumbledore to extinguish street lamps, creating darkness."
"Madam Pomfrey is mentioned in a humorous anecdote by Dumbledore, indicating a familiarity between them."
"Lemon drops are offered by Dumbledore to Professor McGonagall and are described as a kind of Muggle sweet that Dumbledore enjoys."
"The cat is a creature that initially watches Dumbledore and later transforms into Professor McGonagall, playing a significant role in their meeting."
"Number four is the location where Dumbledore sits on the wall next to the cat, which later turns out to be Professor McGonagall."
"The Dursleys are mentioned as a family whose dark living-room window is used as a reference point in the conversation between Dumbledore and Professor McGonagall."
"The wizarding world is the community of magical people discussed by Dumbledore and Professor McGonagall, who are concerned about its exposure to Muggles."
"The rumor refers to the speculations about why Voldemort has disappeared and what finally stopped him, which is a central topic of the conversation."

relationships.description: "Dumbledore and Professor McGonagall have a conversation about the state of the wizarding world and the disappearance of Voldemort."
"Dumbledore is concerned about the Muggles noticing the activities of the wizarding world and potentially discovering their existence."
"Professor McGonagall is worried about the Muggles finding out about the wizarding world due to the careless behavior of wizards."
"Dumbledore discusses Voldemort's disappearance and his powers, showing a complex relationship between them."
"Professor McGonagall expresses her fear and respect for Voldemort, and discusses his disappearance with Dumbledore."
"Dumbledore ensures that Mrs. Dursley and others like her would not be able to see the magical activities happening on the pavement."
"Dedalus Diggle is suspected to be the cause of the shooting stars in Kent, indicating his possible involvement in the exposure of the wizarding world."
"Dumbledore uses the Put-Outer to extinguish street lamps, indicating his control over the device."
"Dumbledore shares a personal anecdote involving Madam Pomfrey, suggesting a close relationship."
"Dumbledore offers lemon drops to Professor McGonagall, showing his fondness for the Muggle sweet."
"Professor McGonagall transforms from a cat into her human form, indicating her magical ability to shape-shift."
"Dumbledore sits on the wall at number four, which is the location of his meeting with Professor McGonagall."
"The Dursleys are mentioned as an example of Muggles who have noticed unusual activities, indicating their awareness of the wizarding world."
"The rumor is about significant events affecting the wizarding world, including the disappearance of Voldemort."

entities.description: "Jim McGuńn is a weatherman who discusses unusual weather phenomena and makes light of the situation."
"Ted is a newscaster who introduces the weather segment and jokes about the mysterious events."
"Kent is a location where viewers reported unusual weather phenomena, specifically a downpour of shooting stars."

"Lily is mentioned as Harry's mother, who was a witch and is remembered for her magical abilities and her tragic end."
"James Potter is Harry's father, a wizard who, along with his wife, was killed, leaving Harry an orphan."
Voldemort, also known as You-Know-Who, is a powerful dark wizard who killed Harry's parents and tried to kill Harry but failed, marking a significant event in the wizarding world.
"Hogwarts is the school of witchcraft and wizardry where Harry's parents were students and where Harry is destined to go."
"Muggles refers to non-magical people in the wizarding world's terminology, and Harry was raised in a family of Muggles."
"Muggle is a term used in the wizarding world to refer to non-magical people, highlighting the distinction between the magical and non-magical worlds."
"Wizard refers to a person with magical abilities, specifically used in contrast to Muggles and highlighting Harry's heritage."
"Witch refers to a female with magical abilities, used to describe Lily and emphasize the magical side of Harry's family."
"The owl is used by Hagrid to deliver the letter to Professor Dumbledore, symbolizing the means of communication in the wizarding world."
"The storm occurs as Hagrid sends the owl with Harry's letter, adding to the dramatic atmosphere of the scene."
"The letter is a significant event as it is the means by which Harry is informed of his admission to Hogwarts and his magical heritage."
"The school refers to Hogwarts, the institution central to Harry's education and the wizarding world's narrative."
"The Łrelight is where Uncle Vernon moves into, becoming a significant location for the confrontation over Harry's magical heritage."
"The car crash is the false story Aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon told Harry about the death of his parents, masking the truth of their fate."
"The rubbish refers to the magical world and practices that Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia tried to suppress in Harry's upbringing."
"The freak is a derogatory term Aunt Petunia uses to describe Lily, reflecting her disdain for the magical world."
"The Potter refers to James Potter, Harry's father, and is mentioned in the context of his marriage to Lily and their tragic end."
"The Muggle is a term used by Hagrid to describe Uncle Vernon, emphasizing the divide between the magical and non-magical worlds."
"The wizard who went bad is a reference to Voldemort, indicating the narrative of his rise to power and the fear he instills."
"The followers refer to those who joined Voldemort, either out of fear or a desire for power, highlighting the dark influence of Voldemort."
"The safe places are locations that remained secure during Voldemort's rise, with Hogwarts being one of them, indicating the importance of these locations."
"The dark days refer to the period of fear and unrest caused by Voldemort's rise to power, affecting the entire wizarding world."
"The Head boy & girl are prestigious roles at Hogwarts, held by Harry's parents, signifying their prominence in the wizarding world."

relationships.description: "Hagrid is responsible for delivering Harry's letter from Hogwarts and taking him to buy his supplies, indicating a guiding role in Harry's life."
"Harry is indirectly connected to Professor Dumbledore through the letter and his upcoming enrollment at Hogwarts."
"Uncle Vernon is against Harry's involvement with the wizarding world, showing a conflicted relationship."
"Aunt Petunia knew about Harry's magical heritage and resented it, contributing to a strained relationship."
"Lily is Harry's mother, and her death has a profound impact on Harry's life and his introduction to the wizarding world."
"James Potter is Harry's father, and his death has left Harry an orphan, shaping Harry's story."
"Lily and James Potter were married and were both witches and wizards, and their deaths were a significant event in the wizarding world."
"Voldemort was responsible for the death of Lily, Harry's mother, making him a direct antagonist to her and her family."
"Voldemort was responsible for the death of James Potter, Harry's father, making him a direct antagonist to him and his family."
("entity"

entities.description: "Hagrid is a character who knew Harry's parents and is involved in the wizarding world, showing sadness and respect towards Harry."
Albus Dumbledore is the highly respected headmaster of Hogwarts, considered one of the greatest wizards, who allowed Hagrid to stay on as gamekeeper after his expulsion.
Voldemort, also known as You-Know-Who, is a powerful dark wizard who killed Harry's parents and tried to kill Harry but failed, marking a significant event in the wizarding world.
The main character who receives a mysterious letter and is a student at Stonewall High, also addressed as Mr. H. Potter in the letter.
"Vernon Dursley is Harry's uncle, who is portrayed as hostile and dismissive towards the wizarding world and Harry's parents."
"Hogwarts is a school of witchcraft and wizardry, where Harry's parents were head boy and girl, indicating their prominence."
"The Dark Side refers to the malevolent and evil aspects of magic, which You-Know-Who is associated with."
"The McKinnons were a family of witches and wizards killed by You-Know-Who, indicating their significance in the wizarding world."
"The Bones were a family of witches and wizards killed by You-Know-Who, indicating their significance in the wizarding world."
"The Prewetts were a family of witches and wizards killed by You-Know-Who, indicating their significance in the wizarding world."
"Halloween is the event on which You-Know-Who came to Harry's house and killed his parents, marking a significant and tragic event."
"The village is the geographical location where Harry and his family lived, and where the tragic event of his parents' death occurred."
"Dudley is Harry's cousin, who often physically abuses him, indicating a hostile relationship."
"The Dursleys are Harry's relatives who provide him a hostile and abusive home environment."
"The wizarding world is the community of witches and wizards, distinct from the non-magical world, and is central to Harry's identity."
"The Death Eaters are a group of dark witches and wizards led by You-Know-Who, known for their cruelty and association with the Dark Side."
"The cupboard is where Harry is often locked by the Dursleys, symbolizing his mistreatment and confinement."
"The killing curse is the powerful spell cast by You-Know-Who that resulted in the death of Harry's parents and many others."
"The mark on Harry's forehead is the result of the killing curse and is a symbol of his survival and fame in the wizarding world."

entities.entity_name: "THE NIGHT YOU-KNOW-WHO TRIED TO KILL HARRY"
entities.description: "This event is significant as it marks the night when You-Know-Who's power was diminished, and Harry survived the killing curse."

relationships.description: "Hagrid has a protective and respectful relationship with Harry, having taken him from his ruined house on Dumbledore's orders."
"Dumbledore has a significant influence on Harry's life, having ordered Hagrid to take him from his ruined house after his parents' death."
"You-Know-Who tried to kill Harry but failed, which is the reason for Harry's fame in the wizarding world."
"Hagrid knew Harry's parents and is aware of You-Know-Who's actions, showing sadness and respect towards Harry."
"Vernon Dursley is Harry's uncle and has a hostile relationship with him, dismissing the wizarding world and Harry's parents."
"Harry's parents were prominent at Hogwarts, which adds to the significance of Harry's own story and potential future at the school."
"You-Know-Who killed The McKinnons, indicating his ruthlessness and the danger he poses to the wizarding world."
"Dudley, as Harry's cousin, is part of the family that mistreats and bullies him."
"The Dursleys are dismissive of You-Know-Who and the wizarding world, showing a contrast in values and beliefs."
"You-Know-Who is a dark wizard in opposition to the wizarding world, causing fear and destruction."
"The Death Eaters are followers of You-Know-Who, committing acts of darkness and cruelty in his name."
"Harry is frequently locked in the cupboard by the Dursleys, symbolizing his mistreatment and isolation."
"Harry is the only known survivor of the killing curse, which is cast by You-Know-Who."
"The mark is a result of You-Know-Who's failed killing curse, symbolizing Harry's survival and the curse's impact."

relationships.src_id: "THE NIGHT YOU-KNOW-WHO TRIED TO KILL HARRY"
relationships.description: "This night is pivotal for Harry as it is when he survived the killing curse cast by You-Know-Who."
